content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: fun, multiple ways to solve it, challenging

funny !

Just fix the 'Input description' part ([[s]] is on line 2)

i see no reason to add a max constraint on [[s]] value (and I would have liked negative values, but maybe it's not compatible with time restriction ^^)
Looks cool! but it take me more than 5 mins to implement

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice idea. Perfect complexity :).
Challenging task! Probably, it'd be more convenient to have a basic example with more different numbers (not only 0 and 9).

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: This contribution is challenging for doing it in time and I like it. It requires some good programming skills. Statement is very clear so u dont spend much time on reading it.

I like the idea! ASCII art in movement - simple and fun.

The formulation is clear. I feel like it is publishable.

My only suggestion is about [[s]] restriction. Is there a reason you restrict it? It's a wheel! I would let it spin freely left and right (modulo arithmetic training).

Thanks for the feedback !
I actually put a constrain on [[s]] because I didn't want people to have to handle too many cases. when the wheel makes a full turn, there is also modulo operations to consider, that can become quickly painful within the time restriction :)
Thanks for your comment, I added a test case including this!
Same for me, but it is feasible largely feasible in less than 15min I think, I saw much more difficult exercise in the past :)

Thanks, I didn't spot the typo, it is fixed now. 

Regarding your comment, I originally had unlimited value on s, with the possibility to go as well clockwise, but each of these subcases needs to be handled separately in the code (for large s, you need to use modulo operations, for clockwise rotation, the way to rearrange the string is slightly different). 

The real core of the challenge is to understand how to handle the input before being able to make the rotation, at least that's what I found interesting in it, the rest can be seen as "secondary" difficulties :)
Up to you but I don't think it is an issue (i.e. too much pain).
